data: Bilingual sign advertising engraving of inscriptions
A rectangular plaque of marble, intact but lightly chipped around the edges and previously broken in half vertically and subsequently reconnected.

The text fills the face of the plaque, divided vertically by a deeply incised line into two unequal halves, with a column of Greek on the left (wider) and Latin on the right). Each column is approximately centred, and consists of seven lines of text, with the first two lines notably larger than the following five.
Greek text includes lunate sigma and epsilon; extended apex to delta and alpha. Latin text is is regular with serifs, open P, closed R. There are no word dividers or punctuation in either text.

Augustan or Julio-Claudian,
                                by the letter forms; also, archaic spelling of some of the Latin, with other Sicilian
                                parallels, rules out much later date (so Wilson 1990); Manni Piraino thinks later 2nd century CE
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.
Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo

l.6 reg., orig. qum

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from autopsy

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Stelai are set out and engraved here for sacred temples together with public works / inscriptions are set out and engraved here for sacred temples together with public works

commentary

Although attribution to Palermo remains uncertain, the fact of a bilingual notice, as well as the infelicities in both the Greek and the Latin text have encouraged scholars to accept a Sicilian origin (noting, for example, the scholiast to Cicero who observed that inhabitants of the island used neither language well!). The nature of the errors, such as cum with the genitive have led some to suggest the text was created by an individual whose primary language was in fact Punic, but the suggestion has not been accepted by all. Most recently Consani (2021) argues that the text is the production of a Latin speaker who translated it literally into Greek.

A rectangular plaque of marble, intact but lightly chipped around the edges and previously broken in half vertically and subsequently reconnected.

marble plaque 15.5 24.5 3

The text fills the face of the plaque, divided vertically by a deeply incised line into two unequal halves, with a column of Greek on the left (wider) and Latin on the right). Each column is approximately centred, and consists of seven lines of text, with the first two lines notably larger than the following five.

chiselled

Greek text includes lunate sigma and epsilon; extended apex to delta and alpha. Latin text is is regular with serifs, open P, closed R. There are no word dividers or punctuation in either text.

Line 1 22 Line 2 20 Line 3 8 Lines 4-7 10 Interlineation line 1 to 2 not measured Panhormus Palermo 38.13205, 13.33561 Augustan or Julio-Claudian, by the letter forms; also, archaic spelling of some of the Latin, with other Sicilian parallels, rules out much later date (so Wilson 1990); Manni Piraino thinks later 2nd century CE Original discovery not recorded. Text from autopsy

Stelai are set out and engraved here for sacred temples together with public works / inscriptions are set out and engraved here for sacred temples together with public works

Although attribution to Palermo remains uncertain, the fact of a bilingual notice, as well as the infelicities in both the Greek and the Latin text have encouraged scholars to accept a Sicilian origin (noting, for example, the scholiast to Cicero who observed that inhabitants of the island used neither language well!). The nature of the errors, such as cum with the genitive have led some to suggest the text was created by an individual whose primary language was in fact Punic, but the suggestion has not been accepted by all. Most recently Consani (2021) argues that the text is the production of a Latin speaker who translated it literally into Greek.
